p: In order to assess salt response of sea fennel, Hamed et al. [ 12] cultivated this halophyte in pots filled with sand by using nutrient solutions at different NaCl concentrations (0, 50, 100, 150, 200, and 300 mM). Plants were harvested 13 weeks after transplanting while NaCl treatments started 8 weeks after transplanting. These Authors reported a biomass production of 1 and 13 g DW plant −1 by using a nutrient solution with 300 and 0 NaCl mM, respectively. Likewise, leaf area increased from 100 to more than 600 cm 2 plant −1 with the same salinity levels, highlighting that sea fennel is moderately tolerant to salinity. Therefore, it is possible to consider C. maritimun L. as a facultative halophyte, since high growth does not necessary mean high salinity levels [ 12].
